key_points: Dave Halls' attorney, Lisa Torraco, says Alec Baldwin did not pull the trigger on the prop gun that fatally shot Halyna Hutchins on the 'Rust' set.
Baldwin also stated in a separate ABC News interview that he "didn't pull the trigger."
The tragic incident took place on Oct. 21 during a dress rehearsal at Bonanza Creek Ranch, near Santa Fe, New Mexico.
Cinematographer Halyna Hutchins died, and director Joel Souza was injured when the gun Baldwin was holding discharged.
The Santa Fe County Sheriff's Office identified Hannah Gutierrez-Reed, the film's armorer, and Dave Halls, the first assistant director, as having handled the gun before the incident.
Halls' attorney emphasized the shooting as a "freak, awful accident" and described Halls as "heartbroken".
No charges have been filed yet, but Santa Fe District Attorney Mary Carmack-Altwies stated "everything is on the table" regarding potential charges.
Investigators searched a gun store for new details but have not confirmed the source of the live rounds used.
Two related ABC specials will air discussing the 'Rust' shooting and featuring interviews with Baldwin and others involved.
Halls communicated a "cold gun" to the crew, indicating the firearm supposedly had no live rounds, according to a search warrant affidavit.
